==Introduction==
GLVis is an OpenGL tool for _accurate_ visualization of _serial_ and _parallel_ finite element meshes and grid functions.

==Latest release==
===[http://goo.gl/S1qFfw glvis-3.0.tgz] | [http://doxygen.glvis.googlecode.com/hg/html/index.html Code documentation] | [http://glvis.googlecode.com/hg/CHANGELOG New features]===

_While we recommend that users download the latest release above, all GLVis releases are available [Releases here]. Please use the [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/issues issue tracker] to report [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/issues/entry?template=Defect%20report%20from%20user bugs] or post [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/issues/entry?template=Question%20or%20Comment questions or comments]._

==Overview==
When started without any options, GLVis [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/OptionsAndUse#Server_mode establishes a server], which waits for socket connections and visualizes any received data in a separate interactive window. This allows for the results of simulations run on a remote (parallel) machine to be visualized on the local user desktop, taking advantage of hardware OpenGL acceleration. GLVis originated from the previous research effort in the (unreleased) AggieFEM/aFEM project.

GLVis can be used to [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/OptionsAndUse#Visualizing_meshes visualize meshes] and a wide variety of [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/OptionsAndUse#Visualizing_functions finite element grid functions], including arbitrary high-order finite element and NURBS solutions. It can run a [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/OptionsAndUse#GLVis_scripts batch sequence of commands] (GLVis scripts), or display [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/OptionsAndUse#Server_mode previously saved socket streams].

GLVis is based on the modular finite element methods library [http://mfem.googlecode.com MFEM], which supports in particular general [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/MeshFormats curvilinear] and [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/NURBS NURBS] meshes, input in [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/CurvilinearVTKMeshes unstructured VTK mesh format] and the visualization of parallel meshes and solutions (either saved in separate files or sent by separate socket connections from each processor). Some examples of its use can be found in the [http://code.google.com/p/glvis/wiki/Gallery Gallery] page.

Though depending on MFEM for its finite element dictionary, GLVis can be used independently for parallel and serial visualization. For example, the _[http://www.llnl.gov/casc/hypre hypre]_ library includes scripts for displaying the numerical results from its parallel example codes through GLVis.

==Examples==
  * Start a socket server: *`glvis`*
  * View a mesh: *`glvis -m star.mesh`*
  * View a mesh with a finite element grid function: *`glvis -m star.mesh -g sol.gf`*
  * View mesh and solution from a run on 4 processors: *`glvis -np 4 -m mesh -g sol`* (assuming data saved in files: `mesh.000000`, ... , `mesh.000003` and `sol.000000`, ...  , `sol.000003`)
  * Use *`glvis -h`* to get help on all command line options.
  * See [http://glvis.googlecode.com/hg/README README] for a detail of the keystroke commands accepted in the GLVis interactive window.
